text: still not sure on this - are hs-site websites supposed to combine/minify custom module css and js? I know it IS supposed to happen with live sites just not sure with hs-sites
actually I’m seeing basically all module assets loading separately
even on a live site
In my experience it happens sometimes and sometimes not. Not tested on hs-site though, only live. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

from talking to Libo Song in the past he said there’s an automated script that tests if combination causes issues, if it fails it doesn’t do anything. I think either it’s been set too sensitively or something might be awry today
good to know

explain your issue?

Sorry, didn’t see your reply!
I need to update a form on my home page and I want to use the staging feature.
But, if i update the form, for the staging page, the form will be updated to my prod page as well, so wrong idea.
If i duplicate the form and use the new one on my staging, when pushing my staging i’ll have a new form (and a wan’t to keep using my current form).
Hey Sebastien! I usually just clone the form then swap it back right before I push the page live.
Does anyone know offhand if there’s a property in the dev info that checks if the user is logged into the account?
Not sure I understand the question, do you mind elaborating on how you’d use this?
If you're thinking CMS Memberships, I believe it is the `request_contact.is_logged_in` property
though using that I believe stops page caching (though i also see a `buffer_mode.is_logged_in` but I am not sure what buffer mode would do against caching)
Hi-- this maybe a silly question-- but I’m considering using custom coded files to build out a site-- using Bootstrap 4-- if I custom code a template- would it still be editable by non-coders?
Yup, you would just have to make sure you include some modules in there for the editable content
such as these here: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/hubl/hubl-supported-tags> or using custom modules
Awesome! Thank you, I really appreciate it :slightly_smiling_face:
no problem, anytime

I could see them also listing URLs for those pages too lol, Javascript all the things

I believe the subscription preferences pages on HubSpot are partially broken when the jQuery version for the domain is set to 1.11.

The subscription module includes jQuery 1.6.2 in the module's code, which can't be edited. This means that, on these pages, there are two jQuery includes and neither can be removed. Portals using jQuery 1.7 don't seem to have any issues, but for portals using jQuery 1.11 the click functions on the checkbox and the surrounding box are broken. This means that users may be unchecking some of the options but the code never actually unchecks them.

You should be able to replicate this on a HubSpot site using jQuery 1.11 by going to the subscription preferences page and clicking in the surrounding box three or more times. Checking the box will only work the first time -- after that the checkbox will uncheck but will never check again and in the code the input is actually checked.

I've tested this on a few portals and this seems to be the issue. Can anyone else confirm?
It seems that those properties have a value of false even if I’m logged in.
There should be an `_hsmem` cookie present if the user is logged.  You can get the from the `{{ request.cookies }}` dict
That cookie is documented here btw <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/kcs_article/reports/what-cookies-does-HubSpot-set-in-a-visitor-s-browser> so it’s safe to use
Excellent, I’ll check that out. Thanks so much.
bookmarked :slightly_smiling_face:
That cookie doesn’t show up in the request, even though I’m logged in. Mysterious.
hmm Ok, I just tested using the developer console in chrome, not the actual `{{requests.cookies}}` token
